questions.text: What is the weight of the Indian reference man in kg?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The weight of the Indian reference man is typically considered to be around 65 kilograms (kg).

  • This figure is based on various studies and statistical data regarding the average weight of men in India across different age groups and regions.

Explanation:

Trace elements are essential minerals required by the body in very small amounts, typically measured in milligrams or micrograms

  • Trace elements are essential nutrients that the body requires in very small amounts, typically less than a few milligrams per day.
  • Examples include iron, iodine, fluorine, zinc, copper, cobalt, chromium, manganese, molybdenum, selenium, nickel, tin, silicon, and vanadium.
  • Over the past few years, additional trace elementshave been identified and added to this list as research continues to evolve.

questions.text: Which of the following nutrients' lack is best tolerated by humans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carbohydrates are the body's primary and preferred source of energy.
  • They provide fuel for essential organs and tissues, especially the brain and muscles.
  • In the absence of dietary carbohydrates, the body first uses stored glycogenas an energy source.
  • Once glycogen stores are depleted, the body shifts to fat metabolismfor energy.
  • This metabolic shift leads to the production of ketone bodies, a process known as ketosis.
  • Very low-carbohydrate dietsmay initially cause symptoms like fatigue, irritability, and weakness.
  • However, the body can adapt over timeand continue to function using fat-derived energy.
  • Although carbohydrates are not strictly essential, they are important for optimal energy levels and metabolic balance.

Protein (Option A): Protein is essential for building and repairing tissues, producing enzymes and hormones, and maintaining proper immune function. Protein deficiency can lead to muscle wasting, impaired growth and development, weakened immune system, and other serious health issues, and its deficiency is generally not well-tolerated by the human body.

Fat (Option B): Dietary fat is crucial for providing energy, supporting cell growth, protecting organs, and absorbing certain vitamins. Fat deficiency can lead to various health problems, including dry skin, hair loss, hormonal imbalances, and impaired brain function. While the body can survive for longer periods without dietary fat compared to protein or carbohydrates, fat deficiency is still detrimental to overall health.

Vitamins and minerals (Option D): Vitamins and minerals are essential micronutrients that play crucial roles in various bodily functions, including metabolism, immune function, and bone health. Deficiency of vitamins and minerals can lead to a wide range of health problems, depending on the specific nutrient lacking. While the body can store some vitamins and certain minerals, prolonged deficiency can have severe consequences for health.

questions.text: NPU (Net protein utilization) value for egg is-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Net Protein Utilization (NPU) of egg is 100, compared to 80 for meat and 75 for milk, reflecting both digestibility and biological value.

  • Eggs provide almost all essential nutrients, except carbohydrates and vitamin C.
  • A standard 60-gram egg contains:
    • 6 g protein
    • 6 g fat
    • 30 mg calcium
    • 1.5 mg iron
    • And yields approximately 70 kilocalories of energy.
  • Each egg contains about 250 mg of cholesterol, which has raised concerns about coronary heart disease (CHD).
  • Egg protein is of the highest biological quality, containing all 9 essential amino acids in ideal proportions.
  • It is considered the reference standard against which other dietary proteins are compared.
  • Except for vitamin C, eggs supply nearly all fat-soluble (A, D, E, K) and water-soluble vitamins in significant amounts.
  • They are also rich in minerals, including calcium, phosphorus, iron, zinc, and other trace elements.
  • Apart from milk, no single food offers such a wide spectrum of nutrients in one source.
  • The Net Protein Utilization (NPU)of egg is 100, compared to 80 for meat and 75 for milk, reflecting both digestibility and biological value. (Option C & D)

The heart of the ICDS program is the network of Anganwadi centres.

ICDS stands for Integrated Child Development Services, which is a flagship program of the Government of India aimed at addressing the nutritional and developmental needs of children under six years of age, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.

  • Anganwadi centres serve as the cornerstone of the ICDS program, providing a range of essential services to children under six years of age, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.
  • These centres are usually located in rural and urban areas and are run by trained Anganwadi workers and helpers.
  • They play a vital role in delivering nutrition, health, and early childhood care and education services to vulnerable populations, making them the heart of the ICDS program.
  • These centres provide a range of services, including supplementary nutrition, immunization, health check-ups, and preschool education for children, as well as nutrition and health education for mothers.

Mother and children (Option A): While the ICDS program does focus on the nutritional and developmental needs of both mothers and children, the primary operational unit or center within the ICDS program is the Anganwadi centre.

CDPO (Child Development Project Officer) (Option B): CDPOs are government officials responsible for overseeing the implementation of the ICDS program at the project level. They supervise and support the functioning of Anganwadi centres within their jurisdiction, but they are not considered the "heart" of the ICDS program.

PHC (Primary Health Centre) (Option C): PHCs are healthcare facilities at the primary level that provide essential health services to rural communities, including maternal and child health services. While PHCs collaborate with the ICDS program to provide healthcare services, they are separate entities and not the core operational unit of the ICDS program.

questions.text: Under ICDS, supplementary nutrition for children below 5-year age is aimed at providing
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under ICDS, supplementary nutrition for children below 5-year age is aimed at providing 500 kCal and 12-15 g protein.

  • Supplementary nutrition is provided to:
    • Children below 6 years of age.
    • Pregnant and lactating women from economically weaker sections.
  • The type of food supplied depends on:
    • Local availability
    • Beneficiary type
    • And the location of the project
  • The goal is to supplement, not replace, the regular diet.

Nutritional Norms (Revised ICDS Guidelines):

  • Children (6-72 months) receive:
    • 500 kcal and 12-15 g protein/day
    • Financial norm: ₹8.00 per child per day
  • Severely malnourished children (6-72 months) receive:
    • 800 kcal and 20-25 g protein/day (Option A)
    • Financial norm: ₹12.00 per child per day
  • Pregnant and lactating women receive:
    • 600 kcal and 18-20 g protein/day (Option B)
    • Financial norm: ₹9.50 per beneficiary per day

Feeding Pattern (Under Revised Guidelines):

  • Children attending Anganwadi Centres (AWCs) are provided:
    • Morning snack (milk/banana/egg/seasonal fruit/fortified food)
    • Followed by a hot cooked meal
  • Children under 3 years, and pregnant/lactating women, receive Take-Home Ration (THR).

questions.text: The diagnostic criteria of acute severe malnutrition include all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While weight-for-height z-score (WHZ) is a valid anthropometric indicator, a WHZ below -2 standard deviations (SD) indicates moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), whereas severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by a WHZ below -3 SD based on WHO growth standards.

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is a life-threatening condition caused by a significant deficiency in nutritional intake. It results in rapid weight loss and physical signs such as muscle wasting and swelling. SAM primarily affects children under five but can occur in individuals of all ages.

Diagnostic Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)

The diagnosis of SAM relies on specific clinical signs and anthropometric measurements:

  • Bipedal Oedema (Bilateral Pitting Edema) (Option A)
    • Swelling in both feet due to fluid retention in tissues.
    • Caused by protein deficiency, which lowers plasma oncotic pressure.
    • A key indicator of kwashiorkor, a form of SAM.
  • Visible Severe Wasting (Option B)
    • Noticeable loss of fat and muscle, giving an emaciated appearance.
    • Often assessed clinically or confirmed with anthropometric tools.
    • Suggests marasmus, another form of SAM.
  • Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm (for children 6-59 months) (Option C)
    • Measured using a color-coded MUAC tape.
    • Useful in field settings where scales and height boards are not available.
    • A measurement under 11.5 cm in children indicates severe acute malnutrition.

questions.text: An adult pregnant female is termed anaemic if her haemoglobin (venous blood) is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During pregnancy, physiological changes occur in a woman's body to support the growing foetus, which can affect her haemoglobin levels. Anaemia in pregnancy is defined as a haemoglobin level below 11g/dL.

  • Anaemia is diagnosed based on haemoglobin concentration in venous blood and the mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC).

The following are the standard cut-off values for haemoglobin and MCHC:

  • At all ages, a normal MCHC should be approximately 34%. Values below this suggest hypochromic red cells, which commonly occur in iron deficiency anaemia.
  • In terms of severity, a haemoglobin level between 10 and 11 g/dlis considered indicative of early anaemia, while a level below 10 g/dl is classified as marked anaemia.

questions.text: Which one of the following bacteria can survive in the Holders method of pasteurization
questions.solution:
Explanation:

While the Holder method kills most pathogenic bacteria, Coxiella burnetii can survive due to its high heat resistance.

  • This is the most heat-resistantnon-spore-forming pathogen found in milk.
  • It is not reliably destroyed by the Holder method.
  • The temperature-time standards for HTST (High Temperature Short Time) pasteurization were developed specifically to ensure the destruction of Coxiella burnetii.
  • Pasteurizationinvolves heating milk to specific temperatures to destroy pathogenic bacteria, while preserving the milk's composition, flavour, and nutritional value.
  • One commonly used method is the Holder (Vat) method, where milk is heated to 63-66°C for at least 30 minutes, then rapidly cooled to 5°C.
  • This method is effective against most common pathogens, including tubercle bacilli and Q-fever organisms, but some heat-resistant organisms can survive.

Methods of Pasteurization:

  • Holder (Vat) Method
    • Milk is heated to 63-66°C for at least 30 minutes.
    • It is then rapidly cooled to 5°C.
    • Suitable for small-scale or rural communities.
    • Not widely used in urban areas due to low efficiency.
  • HTST Method (High Temperature Short Time)
    • Milk is heated rapidly to 72°C and held for at least 15 seconds.
    • It is then rapidly cooled to 4°C.
    • This is the most widely used method today.
    • Can process large volumes of milk efficiently.
  • UHT Method (Ultra-High Temperature)
    • Milk is heated to 125°C for a few seconds only, typically in 2 stages (the second under pressure).
    • It is then rapidly cooled and bottled immediately.
    • Allows for extended shelf life without refrigeration (if aseptically packaged).

Salmonella typhi (Option A): This organism is not heat-resistant and is effectively killed by the Holder pasteurization process.

Mycobacterium bovis (Option B): Although more heat-resistant than many bacteria, it is destroyed by standard pasteurization methods, including the Holder method.

Brucella melitensis (Option D): This bacterium is sensitive to heat and is effectively killed during Holder pasteurization.
